_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Marion Water Treatment Plant (WTP) is a two million gallon per day potable water treatment plant supplying the City of Marion, IL (population 15,000) and a sattelite supply, the Wye Water District (approximate population 1000), with drinking water.

The present plant was upgraded in 1987 at the site of the previous water treatment plant and is located at approximately the center of town.

As required in the State of Illinois, water is disinfected at the Marion Water Treatement Plant with gaseous chlorine, mixed with water, applied at several feed points in the treatment plant.

The chlorine is supplied by DPC Enterprises of Festus, Missouri, and delivered to the water treatment plant, in steel ton containers,as a liquified compressed gas.  The ton containers are received and kept in a separate room with proper handling and storage and feed equipment with a maximum of 4,000 pounds and average of 2,000 pounds in storage.

The storage room is a 15' x 15' steel reinforced enclosure with two outward opening doors.  A chlorine monitor can detect low levels of chlorine and activate an alarm and an exhaust fan located at floor level.  This is tested at least once per week.  The containers are moved on to container cradles by use of a mon orail with a  lifting beam.

The water treatment plant is manned by at least one person, twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week.  In the event of a chlorine leak, this person has been instructed to first determine the extent of the leak and if more than one helper is needed, to call the Marion Fire Deptartment (also manned twenty-four hours a day) for assistance.

Each operator on duty has been instructed on safety procedures and hazards associated with chlorine handling and emergency response.  Within the past two years we have received instruction from the Marion Fire Department on the used of self-contained breathing apparatis and protective clothing needed to go into a chlorine filled environment.  All personnel have access to

MSDS sheets and safe chemical handling intructions are available for review.  

Emergency response procedures and emergency telephone numbers are posted in the water treatment plant lab for quick response time.  In addition, the city has a safety director who regularly has had safety and first-aid training at the job site during working hours.

In a worst case release, the Marion Fire Department would be the first agency to respond for leak repair or containment and evacuation of the affected area.  The Marion Fire Department would have assistance with evacuation from the Marion Police Department and Williamson County Emergency Management Agency.(LEPC)  

Water plant and fire department personnel have been instructed on using the ton container repair kit "B" which is designed to contain most leaks encountered with containers.  To minimize risk from late night/early morning leaks, container changing is only done from 7:00 a.m. - 2:00 p.m., Monday-Friday by the plant superintendant and assistant.

The chlorine leak detector and feed equipment were both updated and installed in December 1998 and January 1999 respectively, and are serviced and calibrated on a yearly scheduled basis by a Honeywell Company service technician.

The chlorine feed system consists of a chlorinator directly mounted to the ton container and uses a single pressurized connection to minimize leaks.  Its all-vacuum operation causes  air to enter the system, in case a malfunction occurs. This prevents gas from escaping.  The system shuts down automatically if the operating vacuum is lost or the water supply to the ejector is interrupted.  The feed system is operated manually so the operator is at the chlorinator when it is turned on and can determine a feed or leak problem immediately upon start-up.

We have had no accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years.

Planned changes to improve safety include more frequent training of both on-site and fire department personnel.  Consideration is

also being given to purchasing an emergency shut off system for the ton container valves. . Instruction and periodic drills in the use of the emergency repair kit including the actual installation of kits on containers will be conducted.
